properties.author: Anna Kugler, Markus Brantl
properties.name: Preservation plan VD 16-2 tiff collection
properties.description: In this preservation plan we evaluate JPEG 2000 as an alternative to the TIFF format we use as storage format for our scanned material. The scanning was done in the course of the VD 16-2 project funded by the German Research Foundation.

basis.documentTypes: TIFF version 6 images that have been mostly scanned with scan robots. The scanned books are from the 16. century.
basis.applyingPolicies: See policy tree. The tree contains policies for digitized material and represents the policies of the Munich Digitisation Centre (MDZ). The tree does not contain policies referring to born-digital material. In the field of digitization the State Library is following the "Praxisregeln im Förderprogramm 'Kulturelle Überlieferung'" by the German Research Foundation (DFG).
basis.designatedCommunity: General public. Everyone can access the material on our official website. Users access a JPEG compressed version of the TIFF master and can choose from two different sizes 100% and 150%.
basis.mandate: Als weltweit bedeutende Universal- und Forschungsbibliothek, Teil der virtuellen deutschen Nationalbibliothek und zentraler Landes- und Archivbibliothek des Freistaates Bayern übernimmt die Bayrische Staatsbibliothek (BSB) dauerhaft Verantwortung für die Sammlung, Erschließung, den Erhalt sowie die langfristige Verfügbarkeit von Wissen und Information in analoger wie in digitaler Form, um damit heutigen wie auch zukünftigen Generationen von Wissenschaftlern, Lehrenden, Studierenden und anderen Informationssuchenden den Zugriff auf das Wissen unserer Zeit zu ermöglichen. Ziel der BSB ist es die urheberfreien Bestände vollständig zu digitalisieren.
basis.organisationalProcedures: We work with a customized and scalable in-house system (Zentrale Erfassungs- und Nachweisdatenbank - ZEND), which controls the whole workflow from production to indexing and long-term archiving.
basis.planningPurpose: We want to evaluate the migration of our TIFF master images to JPEG 2000. JPEG 2000 is supposed to have several advantages such as steaming and reduced storage consumption using lossless compression. Also our two JPEG access copies used for presentation to the user could become obsolete.
basis.planRelations: This is our first preservation plan. No relations to other plans.
basis.preservationRights: The VD 16-2 collection is free of copyright, thus no restrictions apply.
basis.referenceToAgreements: The master images are stored at the Leibniz supercomputing center which is responsible for security and update of storage media. Different contracts for storing apply but in case of the VD 16-2 collection the Leibniz supercomputing center was a cooperation partner.

trigger.description: JPEG 2000 is becoming increasingly important for libraries. We want to take a look at this file format and evaluate it with respect to our collection and requirements.

policy.name: Target format shall be OPEN, unless impossible
Target format must have open specification
Target format specification must be available
File formats of output manifestations must be supported by existing hard- and software
File format must be suitable for cross-media publishing
Grayscale and color images shall be in TIFF uncompressed
Bitonal images can be in TIFF Group 4

policyNode.name: Images scanned with highest possible resolution to ensure authenticity (protection of investment)

policy.name: For authenticity image must contain the 'resolution'
For authenticity images must contain the 'color profile'
JPEG must not be used for arching
Master image must be convertable to a browser supported format (e.g. JPEG, PNG)
Target format must not have encryption
Access copy of images must be embeddable in PDF
Target content must be authentic
Target content must maintain quality
Target content must remain identical
There shall be expertise for the preservation action
Preservation action must be inline with predefined business processes
Best practice in active preservation management shall be followed
Copyright ownership must be obeyed
Standard must be compliant with OAIS
All data collections must be protected and kept secure during preservation
Metadata standards METS and TEI-P5 are preferred
nestor criteria catalog must be followed
Preservation action tool shall be OPEN SOURCE
Preservation action tool shall be FREE OF COST
Secure networking and communications equipment shall be used
Servers must be protected by power surge protection systems
Disaster recovery procedures must be in place
Original data carriers shall not be preserved
Adequate storage capacity must be maintained for all holdings
Physical carriers must be stored in a physical environment that is suitable ans secured for long-term preservation
Content shall be stored on different locations
Target file size must not be larger than source
Metadata must be stored in vendor independent format
All metadata as described in institutional set of metadata have to be preserved
Content must be preserved unaltered
Preservation action must be validated for authenticity of the substantive content
Preservation action must be documented with target object to be able to trace changes
Preservation action must be emulation
Preservation action must be migration
Preservation action must create platform independent objects
Digital objects for which there is no printed backup must be preserved
Before ingesting in the preservation system, documents must be put in quarantine
Preservation actions shall be accompanied with formal documentation specified in the preservation strategy procedures
Preservation action must be without compression unless no information loss occurs
Prefer preservation actions which are more stable
Prefer preservation actions which are better supported
Preservation action shall optimise the use of space for storage purposes
Preservation actions must be compatible with the existent environment
For authenticity the 'resolution' and 'color profile' must be preserved

sampleRecords.samplesDescription: We choose sample records with slightly different file size, dimension, and different ICC color profiles. They have been taken from the Bible and Thierbuch collection.

collectionProfile.collectionID: The preservation plan applies to the whole collection VD 16-2. The collection itself doesn't have an ID, however each sanned books has a unique ID such as bsb00024266 for the Thierbuch. The file name for a particular page from that book contains the book ID plus the number of the page: bsb00024266_00003.tif.
collectionProfile.description: The collection has been scanned in the course of the VD 16-2 project. In contrast to other collections this one has mostly been scanned using scan robots. Manual scanning had to be used for problematic pages resulting in TIFF files with different resolution, dimension and/or color profiles.
collectionProfile.expectedGrowthRate: Scanning has been finished so no growth expected.
collectionProfile.numberOfObjects: The collection contains 21.000 prints from the 16. century owned by State Library with about 3 million pages. The size of the collection is about 72 TB.
collectionProfile.typeOfObjects: TIFF version 6, one image per page.

requirementsDefinition.description: The requirements have been elicited in a workshop together with the following participants: - Head of Digital Library/Munich Digitization centre at Bavarian State Library - Employees from the Bavarian State Library, department for digitization - Employees from the Leibniz supercomputing center responsible for archiving the digital objects.

resourceDescription.reasonForConsidering: There is no urgent risk identified for TIFF version 6, it's widely used and open.

alternative.name: ImageMagick - TIFF to JP2
alternative.description: Version: ImageMagick 6.5.3-5 2009-06-11 Q16 OpenMP http://www.imagemagick.org Copyright: Copyright (C) 1999-2009 ImageMagick Studio LLC

resourceDescription.reasonForConsidering: We already use ImageMagick for creating the access copies.

experiment.description: The experiment will be carried out on a Intel Core 2 Duo CPU, U9400 @ 1.40 GHz, 2 GB RAM running Windows XP, Version 2002, Service Pack 2. No other computational intensive operations will be carried out during the migration process. The machine will be used exclusively for the migration experiment.

alternative.name: GraphicsMagick - TIFF to JP2
alternative.description:
GraphicsMagick 1.3.6 2009-07-25 Q8 http://www.GraphicsMagick.org/ Copyright (C) 2002-2009 GraphicsMagick Group. Additional copyrights and licenses apply to this software. See http://www.GraphicsMagick.org/www/Copyright.html for details.
GraphicsMagick is originally derived from ImageMagick 5.5.2 but has been completely independent of the ImageMagick project since then.
From the online help: Here are some reasons to prefer GraphicsMagick over ImageMagick:
* GM is much more efficient (see the benchmarks) so it gets the job done faster using fewer resources. * GM is much smaller and tighter. * GM is used to process billions of files at the world's largest photo sites (e.g. Flickr, see John Allspaw's presentation). * GM does not does not conflict with other installed software. * GM suffers from fewer security issues and exploits. * GM comes with a comprehensive manual page. * GM provides API and ABI stability and managed releases that you can count on. * GM provides detailed yet comprehensible ChangeLog and NEWS files. * GM is available for free, and may be used to support both open and proprietary applications. * GM is distributed under an X11-style license ("MIT License"), approved by the Open Source Initiative. * GM developers contribute to other free projects for the public good.

resourceDescription.necessaryResources: Behaviour and usage (especially command line parameters) of GraphicsMagick are similar to ImageMagick. Since we heavily use ImageMagick in the Bavarian State Library no considerable effort is necessary for running GraphicsMagick.
resourceDescription.reasonForConsidering: GraphicsMagick is said to be better than ImageMagick for migrating to JPEG 2000.

experiment.description: The experiment will be carried out on a Intel Core 2 Duo CPU, U9400 @ 1.40 GHz, 2 GB RAM running Windows XP, Version 2002, Service Pack 2. No other computational intensive operations will be carried out during the migration process. The machine will be used exclusively for the migration experiment.

alternative.name: Kakadu - TIFF to JP2
alternative.description: Kakadu V6.1. Kakadu ships with several compiled commands for various application areas. We use the kdu_compress.exe command from the suite. Currently accepted image file formats are: TIFF, RAW (big-endian), RAWL (little-endian), BMP, PBM, PGM and PPM

resourceDescription.necessaryResources: The usage_examples.txt file which is included in the downloaded version accurately explains which command has to be used using which parameter settings for lossless migration.
resourceDescription.configSettings: kdu_compress -i <input file> -o <output file> Creversible=yes -rate -,1,0.5,0.25 Clevels=5 Adopted from Kakadu's usage_examples.txt file
resourceDescription.reasonForConsidering: Kakadu is a powerful open-source, although license-fee bound library for converting images and video files. The "Truly Lossless JPEG2000 Compression" article which can be found at http://dltj.org/article/lossless-jpeg-2000/ reports positively on this tool.

experiment.description: The experiment will be carried out on a Intel Core 2 Duo CPU, U9400 @ 1.40 GHz, 2 GB RAM running Windows XP, Version 2002, Service Pack 2. No other computational intensive operations will be carried out during the migration process. The machine will be used exclusively for the migration experiment.
experiment.settings: kdu_compress -i <input file> -o <output file> Creversible=yes -rate -,1,0.5,0.25 Clevels=5 These parameter settings were taken from the Kakadu Usage_Examples.txt.

alternative.name: GeoJasper - TIFF to JP2
alternative.description: GeoJasper 1.3.1. GeoJasper is a Geo supporting transcoder based on enhanced jasper library (i.e., it converts image data from one format to another) correctly transferring geo information between GeoTiff and GeoJP2(tm).

resourceDescription.necessaryResources: GeoJasper gives very detailed usage information and is thus easy to use. It can be downloaded as zip archive and simple copied on the hard disk. From that point on GeoJasper is ready.
resourceDescription.reasonForConsidering: GeoJasper is reported to be one of the most frequently used tools for TIFF to JPEG2000 migration.

experiment.description: The experiment will be carried out on a Intel Core 2 Duo CPU, U9400 @ 1.40 GHz, 2 GB RAM running Windows XP, Version 2002, Service Pack 2. No other computational intensive operations will be carried out during the migration process. The machine will be used exclusively for the migration experiment.

decision.reason: In some pre-tests LuraWave was the only tool that successfully preserved the image resolution of our TIFF images. However, due to the fact that it's not open source we don't consider it in this evaluation.
decision.actionNeeded: Carry out the experiments using these tools.

evaluation.comment: For evaluating image identity two tools were used. ImageMagick compare and GraphicsMagick compare. Only if both tools report that no pixels are different we consider the original TIFF image and the migrated JPEG 2000 image identical.

recommendation.reasoning: As the evaluation shows keeping the status quo is the preferred preservation action. The resulting JPEG 2000 files do not fulfill our requirements. At the moment it looks as if the tools do not migrate the files correctly. However further investigation on the JPEG 2000 file format must be done because we haven't yet found out if the tools fail to preserve the color profile or if the JPEG 2000 standard doesn't allow the profiles. The JPEG 2000 Extension (JPX) allows custom color profiles but we do not intend to migrate to this format as only the core part of JPEG 2000 is royalty and license-fee free.
recommendation.effects: We do not migrate the TIFF collection yet but revisit the plan within the next 6 - 12 months for re-evaluation. Maybe the tools will improve and suite our need more.

leaf.name: image size identical
leaf.description: This requirement also says something about the stability of the tool used for migration. In case the tool crashes the image size might not be identical. The same pertains to "image identical"

leaf.name: image identical
leaf.description: The pixel information must be the same. This requirement also says something about the stability of the tool used for migration. In case the tool crashes the image might not be identical. The same pertains to "image identical"

alternative.comment: artist,datetime of creation,used software are lost
artist,datetime of creation,used software are lost
artist,datetime of creation,used software are lost
artist,datetime of creation,used software are lost

leaf.name: original size identical
leaf.description: If the 'original size' was preserved. If this information is lost the digital image is not authentic any more because the size of the scanned page is lost.

leaf.name: existent OCR still valid
leaf.description: If there is OCR data from the source image is available can it be applied to the migrated object or do we have to OCR the migrated objects again? This mainly refers to (x,y) location information OCR contains.

alternative.comment: Based on LoC File Formats Database
Based on LoC File Formats Database
Based on LoC File Formats Database
Based on LoC File Formats Database

leaf.name: OCR possible
leaf.description: Whether there is software available that can OCR from that file format. There is plenty of software for TIFF for instance.

leaf.name: reversible migration wrt. pixel information
leaf.description: Did pixel information change. We can test that by comparing the source image with a TIFF version that has been generated from the migrated object.

alternative.comment: But TIFF meta data is lost
But TIFF meta data is lost
But TIFF meta data is lost
But TIFF meta data is lost

leaf.name: master = access copy
leaf.description: Can we use the master image also as access copy? This would reduce the number of derivatives we need and the storage necessary.

leaf.name: publishers can work with master
leaf.description: Publishers often access our collection. In contrast to users accessing the collection via the web, publishers need the high resolution version of the image which is the TIFF master. We never had issues or had to migrate the file before publishers could use them. Potential new master formats should fulfill this requirement.

alternative.comment: As it's well supported by Photoshop
As it's well supported by Photoshop
As it's well supported by Photoshop
As it's well supported by Photoshop

leaf.name: Licensing
leaf.description: Do any fees apply? JPEG 2000 for instance has 17 patent holders. Is that a problem?

alternative.comment: core part is free of costs
core part is free of costs
core part is free of costs
core part is free of costs

node.name: migration process
node.description: The Leipzig supercomputing center is currently following a "pay per volume" model. Depending on the volume that is retrieved from or (re-)ingested into the archive. A migration project would mean we pay for retrieving and reingesting.

leaf.name: adaptions of existing system
leaf.description: Estimation of the costs for adapting the current system in the Bavarian State Library to the new master format. A detailed breakdown of the costs will be done in the next revision of this plan. At the moment a single figure should be provided.

executablePlan.triggersConditions: We don't migrate our master images at the moment.
executablePlan.validateQA: We don't migrate our master images at the moment.

trigger.description: In 6 - 12 months we'll look at this plan again to see if there are more tools available or the ones we considered in our evaluation improved. Furthermore, by then JPEG 2000 could be better supported by browsers. This would enable us to use the master copy also as access copy to reduce total memory consumption since our 2 - 3 access copies would become obsolete.

It may be an option to store the ICC profiles separate from the master images. As this would mean a rather large change to our archival system a detailed evaluation is necessary. Once the evaluation is done we revisit this plan.
